pros: A nice community , easy to get time off, get to create own schedule .

job_title: Technical Records Specialist I in Pocatello, ID
pros: Everyone with this job title has different responsibilities, so it's not apples to apples comparison. The pros are that your job is protected status, and responsibilities are divided up enough that they aren't ever really overwhelming. I never take work home with me. The benefits, especially PERSI retirement is fantastic. My favorite part is the work atmosphere. It comes naturally with the territory of helping students progress and apply themselves to bettering their lives. It's a pretty cool thing.
cons: It's menial office work a lot of the time. My mid-level managers are not very good at their job, which leads to some interesting decisions and outcomes. I'm a male in a female-dominated field, and a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and have on occasion felt discriminated against for both reasons.

pros: Good environment and friendly people
cons: Minimum pay and bad weather in winter

pros: The PERSI, flexibility during COVID, Health Insurance and a good teamwork mentality.

- Work on homework at work.
- Minimal effort required.
- Flexible hours, they'll work with your school schedule.
cons: - Low hourly rate ($8.00/hour).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pocatello, ID
pros: Good way to get a cheap education.  There's not a lot of motivation to work for ISU because this institution has lost focus on what it's main goal is- to serve students and not it's own interests.  It's too bad, really, because this place was good as early as 4 years ago. Perhaps I'm just disenfranchised, but the school can't seem to hold onto talented professors and the internal struggling and politiking that happens.  I understand that this part of the review is supposed to be the positive part of the review, but there simply isn't much to say that's good for the university.
cons: Long hours in the lab, and teaching subjects that you don't have that much background information on.  I understand that this job is a graduate student, and as such, it is a nasty job that people should not want to have, but the idea of trial by fire and turning you into a scientist seems a little outdated, much like trying to keep a medical student/intern awake for 60 hours and still keeping coherent enough to not bumble and accidently kill someone.  It just doesn't make a lot of sense to me.  Get in, get your education, and get out!

pros: People, Experience, Students, Hours, Schedule.
cons: Management gets paid pennys so they barely assit on anything

pros: ISU is a great place to work as a student
cons: I just wish I could work a full 40 hours.

pros: Fun and easy job for students
cons: There are few hours to work and sometimes you can't do homework

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Bonners Ferry, ID
pros: Tons of training and development opportunities. Discount for classes.
cons: Funding is unstable due to government funding.

pros: I love working for the university
cons: Can't think of any right now.

review_title: It was a living hell.  I had to take medication just to get by.
pros:
The benefit package is pretty good.  Insurance coverage is good, vacation and sick leave benefits start out good, and increase with seniority, and staff members can take classes for $5.00 per credit hour, and $20.00 to register.  

Classified state employees are not at-will employees, and can not be fired without cause.
cons:
The entire organization is corrupt.  Petty egos run things, and from the top down, no one is allowed to ever question a superior. 

Managers are incompetent, and ambitious for themselves.  Little or no care is given to the good of the institution.  Instead, the only consideration is to the advancement of the career of the manager. If anyone causes a manager any embarrassment to his higher ups, for any reason, there is no saving that career.  It will be destroyed.

Idaho State University offers little or no academic freedom for professors either, and has been placed on the American Association of University Professors' Sanctioned list. Due to Arthur Vailas' dissolution of the Faculty Senate, and purge of university professors that have disagreed with him.

review_title: Love my job, but it is not without questionable moments.
pros: Working for my department and with my co-workers is a great experience. I hope to be here for a long time.
cons: The upper administration tends to "surprise" the employees on a regular basis with budget concerns which leads to a stressed work environment. The restructuring that was implemented to cut costs and improve efficiency has more than doubled the administrative workload on departments. Also since the restructuring took effect the HR department is the worst I have ever dealt with, they opperate like a nightmare insurance company straight out of a Grisham novel. It makes a worker wish for some sort of organization with the power to look out for them.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pocatello, ID
pros:
I'm contracted to TA 2-3 classes each semester in the Geosciences Department at ISU.  The work load is supposed to be under 19 hours/week, however there is no formal system for tracking work hours. 

Generally, faculty try not to overload you with TA assignments.
cons:
Low pay rate is set at $12,775 for the 9-month school year by the Idaho State Legislature. The university does not seem to be doing anything to lobby for graduate teaching assistants to be paid a higher rate. ISU also does not provide health insurance and it can be difficult to afford on such a low salary. 

Work hours are not tracked and if you're over worked there sometimes isn't anything you can do about it. 

No teaching skills training is provided and support for non-academic issues that arise while TAing is limited to non-existent.

review_title: I worked as a Capacity Builder directly with Principals and Superintendents to assist with staff and student improvement
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Buhl, ID
pros: I loved working directly with school and district leadership to coach and support leadership improvement and system change.  I facilitated support for leadership to bring about needed change and also facilitated new and improved teaching strategies and leadership team involvement in data driven decision making.
cons: In moving to Arizona, there was not a state facilitated support group of leaders so finding how to bring my skills and expertise to schools in need here has been difficult.

review_title: Ask yourself why AARUP would pull accreditation then find out
pros: Most employees are very friendly and helpful, those who are not sycophants of the President and his cronies.
cons: Do the research yourself, there are plenty of cons to find.  I suggest starting with why AARUP would want to pull accreditation.  You might also want to investigate the recent legal actions against ISU admin relating to freedom of speech.  Cronyism is ruining the university.  Vailas wants to run ISU like any other business and he can't see (and his cronies don't care) that universities are actually NOT like other businesses.

review_title: Don't Touch It With A 10 Foot Pole
pros: Most people can have a flexible schedule. It is a major employer in a depressed SE Idaho town (Pocatello). Many of the people are good.
cons: Supervisors are out of control, Because it is important in the town economy, it attracts psychopaths who think they can do anything they want and it hurts everyone, both employee morale and community attitudes toward it. There is no rational policy that rewards good work and reprimands bad. A former employee was publicly insulted by the circulation of a memo condemning him to all staff and faculty, and no one was reprimanded. That individual summed it up by saying it was characterized by prison yard politics.

pros: Benefits - dependant and spouse tuition reduction,  retirement plan.
cons: Administration and management. Administration is exempt from following policies. No transparency with leadership and there seems to always be a secret agenda. If you have or get a job at ISU, don't trust anyone and document everything.  Spend more time managing crises than doing important work.

review_title: Working at ISU is pleasant, but living in Pocatello is not!
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Pocatello, ID
pros:
- The overall atmosphere in the College of Business for faculty and staff is good.
- The university offers interesting programs in different colleges including science and engineering as well as business.
cons:
- The culture, missions, and goals are too much oriented toward teaching and offering new programs (most of which die in a few years) than doing cutting edge research. For those who are interested in teaching side of professorship, this is a good place to be at.
- The town is extremely boring, in particular because of the predominant faith in that area, you may not find any good pubs, bars, or even cafes in Pocatello. It makes it difficult for people from other ethnic, cultural, and religious groups to live happily in that area.

pros: Campus and surrounding area are pretty
cons: Bad administration; shrinking budget; unstable university that is downsizing. Stressful place to work. Stay away from working here if at all possible. Most who work here are not treated well. Also, the university is not run in a way that is good for students. The graduation rate is very low. So, students end up owing a lot for their education and often don't get a degree with which to earn money.

review_title: Okay place to work if you are looking for a state type job without being an employee of the state.
pros: ISU offers great educational benefits, vacation benefits, and nice co-workers.
cons: Management had a habit of asking for input from the employees, but 99% of the time they have already made their decisions and are not open to suggestions. They have, in the last year, lost several great faculty members and staff members because of their lack of flexibility. It's very disheartening to work there and see the best leave.

review_title: Faculty running high school politics fighting over no resources
job_title: Assistant Professor (Tenure Track) in Pocatello, ID
pros: The standards are so low you will get tenure
cons: The culture at this business is abysmal. The Department of Psychology has to hire someone every single year without growth because no one will stay in that backstabbing, backwards department. There are married couples in the department who complain together against faculty for bizarre reasons. Since they do not prepare their graduate students to compete on the national stage, your service gets roped in to awful departmental annual awards. The priorities are completely misplaced. They did not know the difference between a grant and a contract. It is better to take a fourth postdoc than to work here as a TT faculty. Pay was a national-low $50,000/annual. I warn my young colleagues not to apply to their annual openings.

pros: Over the years I have had some wonderful colleagues and students.  Pocatello has unbelievable outdoors opportunities.
cons:
The university administration is working very hard to destroy it.  Most of the good faculty have left.  Programs are losing accreditation.  They lie about the enrollment.  The graduation rate is criminal.  The purpose of the university is to lure students to take loans without actually letting them graduate; the result is that the university gets the money while the students pay the loans.

The administration tell faculty to gie higher grades in order to delay the inevitable dropping out.

It is possible that the university could lose its accreditation.

pros: The university atmosphere, the laid back small city of Pocatello,  and the close proximity to the mountains make this a great place to work and live.
cons: The only downside in my experience was that my job was a temporary, intern position, meaning it didn't pay very much, it didn't have any real job security, and I don't think was ever viewed by others like a permanent part of the team. Otherwise, it was the best job I've had in a long time, and I've had many different jobs.

review_title: If you are looking to start your career in Higher Education, Idaho State University is a good place to work.
pros: ISU offers a nice work environment in a friendly town. Most of the managers are very helpful and will work with you.
cons: There seem to be constant budget concerns, and ISU relies heavily on state funds, which with the current economy, can cause some problems.  Information flows from the top down but is not very helpful.

review_title: Great people to work with, and stability, but no future.
pros: It was a very laid back place to work, and for the most part you worked on your own, with little supervision. The other employees where really good to work with as well.
cons: Too much red tape. It was hard to get any changes through. Pay scale is very low compared to working for a private company. There wasn't a lot of opportunities for growth or to move around in the organization.

review_title: Public university transitioning to corporate model
pros: Met some great people there, and the area has a lot to offer if you like the outdoors.
cons: Sanctioned by the AAUP.  President and crew dismantled the normal elected Faculty Council, and replaced it with one that is "advisory only" with the complicity of the state board of education.  Not a great place to work if you value academic freedom and actual representation in university matters.

review_title: Good job for many years.  No regrets in leaving.
pros: Small enough to get broad based experiences.  There are a lot of great faculty and staff that are passionate about what they do.
cons: Everyone is cutting costs except for administration and finance.  The great faculty and staff are leaving and going to places where they feel appreciated.

review_title: My experience at ISU has been that it was a really descent job that I have enjoyed.
pros: They had really flexible schedules. I did not work as a teacher here so I didn't get any benefits or anything like that,  but my boss was a great guy.
cons: It was a little monotonous at times. If you don't enjoy being around people that make fun of you every once in a while then this would not be a good place for you to work.

job_title: Electrical Automation Lab Assistant in Pocatello, ID
pros: ESTEC had amazing equipment for their labs. They focused on making sure the student had hands on experience with the latest instruments, calibration tools, controllers and software. They were very supportive in making sure I had what I needed in the lab. They wanted to me to have the opportunity to develop my abilities as well.
cons: Paying to park in a small town like Pocatello Idaho!

review_title: Great if you are a student
pros: Most on campus jobs will work around your class schedule. You choose how many hours you want to work too. I loved my on campus job while I was going to school. Super convenient
cons: You are on campus so much that you quite frankly get sick of it. By the end of the semester I would use any excuse to get a break from all the big brick buildings.

job_title: Tutor and TA in Pocatello, ID
pros:
The different colleges houses some of the best department PhD and instructors in the US.
The school has many many benefits including a student clinic and pharmacy.
The school is untraditional for  all aged people .
cons: The parking is  out of control for price and no available spots.

job_title: Office Specialist II/Transcript Evaluator Senior in Pocatello, ID
pros: Working with faculty, staff, and students to help in graduation procedures, processes.  Work with student files to prepare for permanent storage.
cons: Working with management who don't adhere to established policies and procedures.  Not being notified of changes to policies and procedures.

pros: Good, passionate people work at ISU.  There are some excellent, world-class academic programs at ISU.
cons: The higher you go, the lower quality employee you see.  Dishonesty and manipulation are at the core of management.  The President seems to be a good guy with the institution's best interest at heart, but the CFO is running the show.

pros: They have amazing benefits! You and your spouse can take undergraduate classes for $5 a credit or graduate classes for $7 per credit. Job security is very nice as well.
cons: Sometimes dealing with the beuracacy can be a challenge and they always seem to have more management than necessary and not enough workers.

You have to work extra hard because of the mistakes of others sometimes

pros: The weather is nice. Classrooms in the new building are equipped with decent technological tools.
cons: No pay until the 5th week of the term. No say in course scheduling. Student retention is stressed over student qualification. International students are highly discriminated against. Cheating is rampant. No faculty association. Disabilities are ignored.

cons: Some employees are too relaxed and are lazy but there is a lot of down time for external work or homework.

pros: You can choose your hours around college courses
cons: you are expected to work hard and clean questionable environments for minimum wage

pros: Good location for those who have interest in outdoor recreation.  University has been a good place to work.  Good balance between research and teaching.

pros: excellent environment, I learned so much there.  Supervisors cared that much was learned and that comprehension was retained

cons: A particular department manager creates a hostile work environment. Both the HR department and the managers own manager have been notified by multiple employees. Nothing has changed. This has been going on for several years.

pros: It was such an amazing place to work at. I met amazing people, made great friends, and learned a lot of new things.

pros: Loved working on projects that mattered. The research was very fun to do and my boss was really great to work for.

pros: Great pay for a student, a stipend is paid every two weeks in addition to tuition being waived for the semester. Lots of flexibility with schedule.

pros: The biology department has changed in the past few years. New professors and great people to with and for.

pros: Good benefits and a constantly changing list of projects.
cons: It's a state job. Everything moves at a glacial pace. The pay rate is so far below market value you have to wonder how they calculate it.

pros: ISU has some of the best and the brightest people working for them. It is stimulating to work with intellectual and driven people.
cons: With any larger company, one can find too many segmented areas.The Divisions are very disconnected.

pros: Idaho has a low cost of living and low-stress living.
